abstract.p: Pianist Johnnie Johnson, inspiration for Chuck Berry song Johnny B Goode, is on tour with five other rhythm and blues greats in W C Handy All-Stars Tour, which is headed for Morristown and Atlantic City, NJ (S)

block.p: Chuck Berry, who helped invent rock 'n' roll, wrote one of his most famous songs, ''Johnny B. Goode'' about his piano player Johnnie Johnson, who has also backed such performers as Keith Richards, Eric Clapton and John Lee Hooker.

Mr. Johnson was given the Rhythm and Blues Foundation's Pioneer Award earlier this fall. Now Mr. Johnson is touring with five other rhythm and blues greats in the W. C. Handy All-Stars Tour, which will play the Community Theater of Morristown on Nov. 10 and Trump's Marina casino in Atlantic City Nov. 12.

Chuck Berry, who helped invent rock 'n' roll, wrote one of his most famous songs, ''Johnny B. Goode'' about his piano player Johnnie Johnson, who has also backed such performers as Keith Richards, Eric Clapton and John Lee Hooker.

Mr. Johnson was given the Rhythm and Blues Foundation's Pioneer Award earlier this fall. Now Mr. Johnson is touring with five other rhythm and blues greats in the W. C. Handy All-Stars Tour, which will play the Community Theater of Morristown on Nov. 10 and Trump's Marina casino in Atlantic City Nov. 12.
The W. C. Handy Awards are given each year in recognition of outstanding rhythm and blues performances and performers by the Blues Foundation based in Memphis.
Little Milton, who was named Best Soul Blues Male Artist of the Year by the Blues Foundation for three years running and who was nominated for a Grammy this year, is also on the bill.

They will be joined by Charlie Musselwhite, a nine-time W. C. Handy Award winner, whose latest album, ''Continental Drifter,'' on pointblank/Virgin records, includes several songs with Eliades Ochoa, the Cuban blues legend.
Duke Robillard, named Blues Guitarist of the Year this year, and Trudy Lynn, who was nominated for ''Best Soul/Blues Female'' twice, will join the ensemble.
